title: Which party's candidate will win the next presidential election in South Korea?
preds:
Previously, I calculated the most likely probabilities of P(Yoon) and P(Lee) that could have generated results of the poll.
These probabilities can be described as "what is the probability that a pollster will vote for Yoon/Lee" that could have most likely generated results of that poll. But after @alter_hugo 's comments on coin flipping, I realized I forgot 1 step.
I have to simulate the election itself.
So I ran 1000 simulations using the above probabilities to try and generate 1000 sample polls (one of these could be the sample polls we have seen on 2 Mar), and 86.7% of these simulations result in a Yoon win.
havent been following well enough, going to consensus in the close here

I'm just going to raise my bet since very few incumbent parties, if any, have survived the COVID-19 pandemic. I understand the Democratic Party of Korea won the 2020 legislative election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_South_Korean_legislative_election) but apparently there is growing discontent among Koreans about restriction measures and higher cases (https://www.dw.com/en/south-korea-business-owners-shave-heads-in-covid-19-curb-protest/av-60578011).

Thanks @alter_hugo for your comments! I really appreciate them! I researched on how to translate poll results into max. likelihood, and I found this:
https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/274211/calculating-the-probability-of-someone-winning-from-a-poll Based on the link, I did a simulation with the previous results, by setting the smallest of the 3 probabilities to 0.01: Likelihood (that produces the poll results earlier) = 5723 (total number of polls for Yoon)*log P(Yoon) + 4817 (total number of polls for Lee)*log P(Lee) + 1529 (total number of polls for Others) * log 0.01 (hardcode this to 0.01 since logarithm doesn't accept 0) I vary P(Yoon) and P(Lee) and select the combo that produces maximum likelihood, which is 55% & 45%.

According to 3 Mar opinion polls of the Wikipedia site as of 7 Mar 2022,
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_South_Korean_presidential_election#Opinion_polling the 5 polls with the largest sample sizes are:
RealMeter - 3037 
Opinion Research Justice, Dalian - 3004 
Embrain Public, JoongAng IIbo - 2013
National Barometer Survey - 2013
Ipsos, Korea Research, Hankook Research - 2003 Now that Ahn endorses Yoon, I will give half of his support to Yoon (an assumption)
RealMeter : Yoon (45.1% + 7.1%/2), Lee (40.6), 
Opinion Research Justice, Dalian : Yoon (46.4 + 6.1/2), Lee (40.7)
Embrain, JoongAng IIbo : Yoon (43.7 + 8.1/2) , Lee (40.4)
National Barometer Survey : Yoon (40 + 9/2) , Lee (40)
Ipsos, Korea Research, Hankook Research : Yoon (42.1 + 6/2) , Lee (37.1) What is not clear to me, is how to factor the error percentage points (in Wiki but not shown here) into the above though. I then get the following:
					SSize	Yoon	Lee	
RealMeter				3037	48.65	40.6	
Opinion Research Justice, Dalian	3004	49.45	40.7	
Embrain Public, JoongAng IIbo		2013	47.75	40.4	
National Barometer Survey		2013	44.5	40	
Ipsos, Korea Research, Hankook Research	2003	45.1	37.1	

I weight the percentages by the total sample size (12070), and get the following: 					        Wgt	        Yoon	Lee
RealMeter				0.25	12.24	10.22
Opinion Research Justice, Dalian	0.25	12.31	10.13
Embrain Public, JoongAng IIbo		0.17	7.96	6.74
National Barometer Survey		0.17	7.42	6.67
Ipsos, Korea Research, Hankook Research	0.17	7.48	6.16
					Final	47.4	39.9

According to three out four polls published between Sunday 27 and Monday 28, compiled by Statista (https://www.statista.com/statistics/1286668/south-korea-voting-intention-for-presidential-election-by-polling-institute/) People Power Party would beat the Democratic Party of Korea by a 2.2% to a 5.1% margin (the fourth poll predicts a tie). As @monicaflorio and @DomHajduk pointed out, People Party's candidate dropping out and endorsing People Power Party would likely tip the balance even more - even if only half the votes of their former 10% is transferred to People Power Party. Undecided poll respondents do not reach 8% in most cases, so their contribution in the election might not be crucial. Though it is important to monitor any events unfolding during the following days.

According to Gallup polling two weeks ago, the election was too close to call.  "A Gallup survey two weeks before the election showed that Yoon’s support stood at 39.0 percent and Lee’s at 38.3 percent, with a gap of just 0.7 percent between them. Ahn Cheol-soo, a renowned software entrepreneur and medical doctor, garnered 9.5 percent support in the poll." Source: https://thediplomat.com/2022/03/south-koreas-nastiest-presidential-election/ Just yesterday, a popular opposition candidate, Ahn Cheol-soo, dropped out of the election and gave his support to Yoon Suk-Yeol.
@DomHajduk - thank you for posting the news about Ahn Cheol-soo giving his support to Yoon Suk-Yeol. Source: http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20220303000683 If the Gallup reporting is correct that Ahn Cheol-soo had 9.5% of the vote, and assuming his supporters will now vote for Yoon Suk-Yeol, I think this tips the election in Yoon Suk-Yeol's favor.

Welp, overnight the Yun - Ahn unity ticket was announced (https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/skorea-presidential-candidate-backs-conservative-may-tip-tight-race-2022-03-03/). The timing is very eyebrow-raising, to be sure, and certainly one cannot simply stack up the polling of both candidates and expect that to be Yuns result next week. However, I think it does give him a significant lead, as Lee support may have plateaued, and it is unlikely that a plurality of Ahn supporters would vote for Lee now, instead of moving to Yun or sitting the election out.
from some current news coverage - seems like how the prospective candidates react to ongoing ukrainian events may influence - but reporting seems to be pretty even split on who may win

While I do think Yoon has a slight edge, I think the current forecast is overly confident in Yoon's favour. While Yoon does appear to have a slight edge in the polling, they have shown a tightening of the race in recent weeks. With both candidates being more unconventional candidates and recent major world events I would expect a wider deviation from polls than under more usual circumstances, and as such I am viewing my base case of the current race as a toss up. Especially if Ahn and the PP remain statistically relevant come voting time, pulling votes from Yoon and the PPP. Ultimately I see the race as a tight race between a candidate in Lee who is looking to make more drastic Progressive reforms across the country and Yoon who is politically inexperienced but represents a more centrist set of policies with a perceived hard on corruption bent. Despite the fact that polls seem to indicate the race is tightening, Yoon's habit for gaffes, and Ahn as a possible vote splitting factor on the right; I see Yoon still having the slight edge.  Ultimately in a time of geopolitical unrest I think the instinct of flight to safety gives the ever so slight edge to the more centrist candidate. Even if I think the current forecast is understating Lee's chances.

Dem approval rating sharply up week on week, Lee courting third party voters, and a return to "form" - gaffes and bumbling - by Yun gets this back to a toss-up. Yun still somewhat ahead, but we have one more debate to go and just over a week, and the trend has swung back to where it was at the start of the year. If Lee ends up winning, he can thank Ahn Cheol-su, as he will need to redirect his supporters to himself, or at least keep them from going (returning?) to Yun.  I genuinely believe the crowd may be mostly running on momentum and overestimating PPP chances, which have now fallen into margin of error territory in most of the polls Ive seen. While the structural trends is likely still with Yun, there just may be enough on-ramps for the Lee camp to get to a majority. Also, Yuns weakpoint may be his wife, whom he reinforced attention on recently, misspeaking and confirming she acted wrongfully in the DM share trading scandal.

PP has withdrawn offer to merge campaigns with PPP. Presumably PPP is confident the polls are going its way. Slightly adjusting my odds in favour of the PPP therefore. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-20/s-korea-presidential-candidiate-scraps-plan-to-unite-with-rival

New polling indicates crystallization of trends that have emerged in the last month - despite being widely seen as more capable, the county just is not feeling Lee, who is now 7 points behind. Broader dynamics and party ID ultimately more impactful than candidate characteristics - unless Mr gaffe per day missteps significantly in the final stretch.

Improving likelihood of PPP winning according to opinion polls. PPP appears to be in talks with PP to merge campaigns, which would significantly boost its chances. However negative campaigning makes the race highly volatile.

It still looks like anything could happen.  Games are being played with Ann as the 3rd candidate. Are the PPP trying to force him out or are they serious about merging?  14 Feb is the deadline for that. I still give the PPP the edge because they are the opposition and it seems there are a lot of negative views on the DP candidate.  But not by much because the PPP also have their own scandals.  very hard to call.

"A Realmeter poll of 3,031 voters commissioned by OhmyNews that ran from Jan. 9 to Friday showed Yoon leading with 40.6 percent support, up 6.5 percentage points from a week earlier. He is followed by Lee Jae-myung of the ruling Democratic Party at 36.7 percent, down 3.4 percent points on-week. Yoon was leading the race with 3.9 percentage points distance from Lee, which is outside the margin of error at plus or minus 1.8 percentage points with a 95 percent confidence level for the latest survey." http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20220117000692 Still too tight to be certain but if PPP has navigated the recent scandal(s) and is again leading polls it shows the underlying strength of their appeal in this election

Pretty consistent polling of roughly 35-40% vs 30%, with not one recent poll in favor of PPP candidate. So if election were today I think the odds are something like 90-95%. However the election is, critically, NOT today and there is lots of time for news to trickle in.  FWIW there is a good qualitative summary of the difference in the candidates here: https://www.gzeromedia.com/the-other-big-elections-of-2022. PPP candidate seems like a bit of a boat rocker relative to what is needed.

https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/South-Korea-election/With-candidate-battered-South-Korea-conservatives-size-up-Ahn
Ahn Cheol-soo of the PP looks to be doing well in polls, hope has risen from only a few pc to 17pc and has a nice upward trajectory.  If this keeps going it could split votes 30/30/30 and then anything could happen.   Lee Jae-myung from the DP has tried to win voters with promises to fund hair transplants in insurance, which is starting to sound a bit desperate. With disillusioned voters and corruption everywhere, a different candidate might be quite appealing,

Opinion polls are still close and reading the articles below, anything could happen to make the result swing either way as both candidates are new to the National Assembly and are handling the change in what seems a not overly competent way and both have corruption allegations
https://foreignpolicy.com/2022/01/06/conservatives-south-korea-presidential-election/
https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2021/12/22/sk-presidential-election-choosing-the-lesser-of-the-two-evils

https://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/2022/01/02/national/2022presidential/Ahn-Cheolsoo-presidential-election-campaign/20220102170746808.html
PPP hasn't been polling as well in the past month or so. "Yoon's ratings suffered in the most recent polls after allegations of his wife using false credentials and disunity within his election campaign". Not sure if there is more to it than that as news is sparse, but as it stands, recovery seems possible. https://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/2022/01/02/national/2022presidential/Ahn-Cheolsoo-presidential-election-campaign/20220102170746808.html
Possible merger, or just chest-beating? I wouldn't weight the probability of this occurring highly, but if it did it's looking like a +10% support for PPP.
"A previous merger negotiation between the PPP and Ahn's People's Party ended in failure in August... The PPP, which had been dismissive of a merger and the viability of Ahn's candidacy, has indicated more openness toward consolidating forces with the People's Party leader."

In the 6th Republic of South Korea, the Presidency has been dominated by either a Conservative (C) or Liberal (L) -
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_elections_in_South_Korea Therefore, I will assume that either a C (People Power Party) or L (Democratic Party of Korea) will win the 2022 South Korean Presidential Election -
Another Candidate = 0% Since the first presidential election in 1987 of the 6th Republic the South Korean Presidency has followed a pattern of the Presidency alternating in two term cycles between the C and L -
1987-1992, 1992-1997 = C
1997-2002, 2002-2007 = L
2007-2012, 2012-2017 = C This pattern is similar to one seen in the US Presidency where in the absence of a recession in the runup to their re-election year (e.g. 1980, 1992, 2020 US Presidential Elections) the ruling party are then re-elected with the opposition party then winning the Presidency in the following Presidential election. Currently the L are in charge -
2017-2022 = L This would suggest that in the absence a recession or some other major disruptive factor occurring in the runup to the 2022 South Korean Presidential Election that L should then win. South Korea did experience a recession in 2020 but it has since recovered -
https://tradingeconomics.com/south-korea/gdp-growth
https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2020/10/27/bouncing-back-south-koreas-recession-ends-as-exports-surge Therefore, my forecast is -
L Winning 2022 South Korean Presidential Election = 80%
C Winning 2022 South Korean Presidential Election = 20%

Very various opinions in our working group, and here is the result of the compromise. DPK comes with legacy, PPP fresher gives tangible chances to PPP. Statistically, DPK should take it, and the dynamic of the last days, in particular around young voters will be decisive.

Opinion polls look thin on the ground so far, but looks fairly level pegging at the moment.  More research to be done 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_South_Korean_presidential_election

In Korea, the president is restricted to a single five-year term in office, so there is no incumbent. The Democratic Party currently has 180 of 300 seats in the National Assembly "However, by April 2021, President Moon's approval rating fell into the low 30s, the lowest of his term"  "Seoul exit polls showed that young voters, who have traditionally sided with the Democratic Party, voted for the conservative People's Power Party (PPP) by huge majorities, by a margin of 55.3 percent to 34.1 percent among voters in their 20s, and 56.5 percent to 38.7 percent among voters in their 30s. In addition, the opposition People Power Party elected 36 year old Lee Jun-seok as the new party chief in June 2021, defeating four other established politicians while putting concerns of young people and opposition for affirmative action at the heart of his pitch and also announcing plans for a 'big tent' approach for the party's appeal to the electorate, which is seen as a generational shift in South Korean politics.[9] Thus the youth vote is seen to be a swing demographic in the 2022 elections." "The People Power Party was formally established in 2020[50] following a merger of multiple conservative parties created in the fallout of the 2016 South Korean corruption scandal"
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_South_Korean_presidential_election "Yoon's (People Power Party) popularity has sagged in recent months as he showed a lack of policy understanding and political experience, and became embroiled in scandals of his own - including murky ties to an anal acupuncturist and corruption allegations involving his family." https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-11-05/south-koreas-ex-top-prosecutor-to-challenge-moons-party-in-2022-presidential-election
Interesting choice of words there... 
"The three experts also agree that prosecutorial investigations involving Lee and Yoon will be key factors in next year’s race, as their outcomes could affect the support and status of the two candidates. Lee is dogged by suspicions of unlawfully favoring his aides for a land development project in Seongnam, Gyeonggi Province, when he was mayor of the city in 2015. Yoon is facing a probe for possibly abusing his power to bring a number of ruling party figures under investigation.
'The prosecution, in essence, holds the key to how this election will unfold,' Rhee said."
That said "A special counsel inspection usually takes three months or more to announce preliminary results, so it is unrealistic to expect any outcome before the election is held," Eom said.
 http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20211128000026 Polls almost entirely favoured the PPP until a recent dive and a narrow lead by the DP. As typical, the vote will likely have more to do with the economy than with the actual candidate. It's sounding like a change election and "Consumption and investment remained weak, weighing on the pandemic-hit economy." (http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20211202000097). Which favours change as well. Its far from certain but I'd give a slight edge to the PPP candidate at this point.
The battle of the crooks vs the crookest, in the spirited way that Koreans fight, the crookest will win.
